content.$t:
image: https://teacheratsea.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/garay_log10.jpg?w=180, caption: Lollie Garay (2009) aboard NOAA ship Hugh R. Sharp, body:

Lollie Garay (TAS, 2009) and Anne Marie Wotkyns (TAS, 2010), in addition to being NOAA Teachers at Sea, also participated in PolarTREC (Teachers and Researchers Experiencing and Collaborating). In an article in Elementa: Science of the Anthropocene, Ms. Garay and Ms. Wotkyns wrote about how teachers and researchers work together to enhance student learning based on their experiences with teacher-scientist partnerships.

“Today we know that students learn better when they experience scientific inquiry more personally. Exposure to research can therefore enhance learning about science.”

To read the article, click here.

gsx$caption.$t: Lollie Garay (2009) aboard NOAA ship Hugh R. Sharp

“Today we know that students learn better when they experience scientific inquiry more personally. Exposure to research can therefore enhance learning about science.”

To read the article, click here.

image: https://teacheratsea.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/channa.jpg?w=180, caption: Teacher at Sea Channa Comer gets a lesson on how to cut rings while aboard the R/V Hugh R Sharp, body:

If you are an alumnus and have recently changed your contact information, please complete the update form and return it to us.

Contact Information Update Form

This form must be completed by alumni after participating in any activity that is directly related to their association with the NOAA Teacher at Sea Program. Activities include, but are not limited to: conferences, presentations, or trips.

Activity Report Form

Also be sure to check out the new Teacher at Sea Alumni Forum to connect with other Teachers and find out about interesting professional development opportunities.

content.$t:
image: http://teacheratsea.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/ed_web.jpg, caption: NOAA's Education Resources Website, body:

If you are searching for educational materials and resources please view these pages:

NOAA Education: NOAA's many educational activities are distributed across   the agency. This site has been designed to help students, teachers, librarians   and the general public access the many educational activities, publications, and   booklets that have been produced.

NOAA's Ocean Service Education: You will find various curricula, lesson plans, and activities at this site. The National Ocean Service (NOS) education resources engage formal and informal   education audiences to build environmental literacy through products and   programs that incorporate the applied science of NOS.

Ocean Careers: If you would like to teach your students about the variety of ocean careers available, please visit this Web site.

content.$t:
image: http://teacheratsea.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/ron-brown-18-february-2012-005.jpg?w=180, caption: Teacher at Sea Alumnus Wes Struble onboard NOAA Ship Ronald H. Brown, body:

The NOAA Teacher at Sea Program application process for the 2015 season is now CLOSED. Applicants will be notified of acceptance or denial into the program by February 2015.

NOTE: The 2015 Teacher at Sea season timeline and selections will be per the federal government appropriation of funds for fiscal year 2015.

gsx$caption.$t: Teacher at Sea Alumnus Wes Struble onboard NOAA Ship Ronald H. Brown
